Jack Sparrow.Action: No direct appearance or action in this excerpt, but Barbossa appears protective of Elizabeth and sarcastic toward guards; Jack's warmth cannot be assessed here.
No direct action or statement from Jack Sparrow in this excerpt to evaluate competence.
Not present or referenced in the excerpt; no actions or statements to evaluate competence.
Mentioned as a Pirate Lord whose presence commands fear and respect among pirates.
Sao Feng expresses a desire to personally send Jack back to the realm of the dead, implying Jack is dangerous and skilled.
Other characters (Will, Barbossa) treat Jack's name with caution and prefer not to mention it openly.
Mentioned as holding one of the Nine Pieces of Eight, requiring others to rescue him.
Holds one of the Nine Pieces of Eight, making him an important player whose return is strategically crucial.
His absence causes chaos and a complicated situation that others have to resolve, implying he left things incomplete.
Jack the Monkey lights a rocket that causes an explosion to create a diversion during their escape.
No direct action or speech by Jack Sparrow in this excerpt; others take charge of intense moments, Jack’s absence shown by omission.
Commands crew to haul halyard and slacken braces immediately after emerging on deck, demonstrating quick assessment and decisive action.
Notices a problem after initial confident assessment, showing awareness and attention to detail.
Expresses no sympathy or patience for his crew, insults them harshly.
Sits alone, slumps and shows vulnerability by reflecting quietly, interacts humorously with a crab.
Tries to pull the Black Pearl with a rope in the sand and fails, demonstrating inability to influence situation physically.
Observes unusual events calmly (stone turning into crab, ship moving on crabs) and reacts with curiosity and interest rather than panic.
Collapses and shows signs of despair or exhaustion.
Remains alert and observant even while in a vulnerable state, noticing the ship moving on crabs and standing to assess the situation.
Appears dramatically riding over the desert sand on crabs, bringing the Black Pearl back, inspiring smiles even from rivals.
Greets Gibbs sharply and with expectation of accountability.
Appears riding on ten thousand crabs carrying the Black Pearl, returns unexpectedly to the group.
Sharp and confident greeting to Gibbs, expecting accountability.
Greets Barbossa with familiarity, calling him by name and recalling past events.
Addresses Tia Dalma with a playful compliment, showing friendliness.
Doubts the reality of others’ presence, acting suspicious and mistrusting.
Looks at Elizabeth with fear, mistrust, and recognition but then turns away, avoiding connection.
Responds sarcastically to their claim of rescue, showing reluctance to accept help or connection.
Steps back to assess the group, histories of betrayal noted but remains pragmatic and willing to cooperate.
Acknowledges Elizabeth's prior attempt on his life bluntly but without malice.
Gives Gibbs another chance, indicating some loyalty or trust.
Rejects Ragetti outright without discussion.
Welcomes Tai Huang's men aboard once convinced of their allegiance, showing inclusivity and practical friendliness.
Responds to Tia Dalma’s teasing in a lighthearted manner, demonstrating tolerance and camaraderie.
Orders the crew to weigh anchor and make way, asserting command as Captain.
Repeats Barbossa’s orders loudly, affirming his role as Captain and asserting his position despite others' claims.
Engages in a power struggle with Barbossa but allows crew member Pintel to voice his opinion before shutting it down, showing some tolerance.
Commands crew to weigh anchor and make way promptly, showing decisiveness.
Examines his compass carefully but is confused/frustrated when the needle won’t move, indicating a momentary loss of control over a key navigational tool.
Repeats Barbossa's orders immediately and loudly, imitating the captain's role but without original initiative or authority.
Argues his claim to captaincy based solely on ownership of the ship, showing assertiveness but not necessarily leadership competence.
Attempts to behave like a captain by ceremoniously using a telescope, but is undercut by Barbossa’s more impressive display, resulting in a deflated reaction.
Jokes about the damaged ship instead of addressing serious damage, showing a lack of urgency or responsibility.
Provides a direction (two degrees starboard) confidently when asked about heading.
Engages in a power struggle over helm control with Barbossa, showing assertion but possibly undermining efficient command.
Puts a consoling hand on Elizabeth's shoulder and looks her in the eye to provide comfort.
Puts a consoling hand on Elizabeth's shoulder, looks her in the eye, signaling steady leadership and emotional support.
Observes and makes note of Swann's words about the heart and the Dutchman captain, showing attentiveness and strategic awareness.
Engages in playful internal dialogue with his multiple selves, shows affection for the sea and humor about rum and salty wenches.
Shows frustration and confusion with the mysterious chart, indicating impatience and self-centered focus.
Encourages others to follow and share his observations about the ship's movement; engages the crew in problem-solving.
Shows excitement and curiosity openly, inviting others to participate.
Leads the crew through the dangerous maneuver of capsizing the ship to save themselves.
Acknowledges the strange and risky situation with a witty remark ('And now up, is down!').
Does not reprimand Pintel for calling the plan stupid, allowing crew members to express frustration without punishment.
Successfully navigates the Black Pearl through a dangerous maneuver causing the ship to roll completely over and then right itself, keeping hold and maintaining composure.
Despite the risky situation, remains calm and confident, symbolized by opening his fist and looking for the black spot without panic.
Relies on crew members to execute parts of the plan (e.g., Pintel and Ragetti tying themselves to the mast), but leads the overall strategy.
Joins in the moment of celebration and shared laughter despite tense standoff.
Refuses to join the group in fighting Beckett, insists on running away.
Argues against going to the pirate gathering, intends to point his ship the other way, showing reluctance and self-interest.
Stops aiming at Will and aims at Elizabeth after she threatens him, showing quick reactive thinking and confident assertion.
Draws a second pistol at Barbossa, matching others readiness in a tense standoff, demonstrating preparedness and skill.
Expresses acceptance to be the last pirate standing, showing resilience and calm in face of threats, indicating mental competence.
Acknowledges the danger but maintains his resolve not to go back to the Locker.
Engages in humorous, playful behavior by extending his telescope far beyond normal length, sharing a moment of levity with Barbossa.
Accepts the uneasy alliance with Barbossa without outright hostility, indicating tolerance and pragmatism.
Says 'Still working on it' when asked about his plan to fight Jones, showing uncertainty and lack of a clear strategy.
Refuses to go back to the Locker, showing strong resolve and determination.
Suggests Will lead the shore party while he stays with the ship, indicating delegation and trust in others' capabilities.
Engages in playful competition with Barbossa by extending his telescope excessively, showing wit but potentially undermining serious strategic focus.
Approaches the Kraken almost reverently, showing respect and depth.
Engages in reflective conversation with Barbossa about survival and hope, showing sincerity and tolerance for different viewpoints.
Reluctantly agrees to summon the Brethren Court, indicating willingness to cooperate and seek unity.
Approaches the dead Kraken reverently and contemplates the situation thoughtfully.
Responds to Barbossa's warning with measured, optimistic remarks about survival and hope.
Reluctantly acknowledges the need to summon the Brethren Court, showing awareness of the stakes.
After being slugged by Sao Feng, he steadies himself, shows no retaliation, and tries to maintain composure by putting on his hat and calling the insult 'square'.
Attempts to be inconspicuous behind Barbossa upon seeing Sao Feng and the enemy situation.
Intervenes indirectly in the negotiation to release Elizabeth by allowing Will Turner to advocate for her.
Acknowledges loyalty of crew by noting which men stand with him, highlighting mutual support and solidarity.
Makes a witty remark about mutiny being from 'the quiet ones,' indicating a light-hearted approach to tense situations.
Expresses subtle disappointment that no one came to save him just out of friendship or care, implying feelings of neglect and desire for sincere bonds.
Does not openly confront or accuse others harshly regarding betrayal or mutiny, instead maintaining a somewhat tolerant tone.
Recognizes that it is often 'the quiet ones' who are dangerous, showing insight and awareness.
Points out allies who would come to save him, demonstrating confidence in his relationships and influence.
Allows himself to be roughly pulled away by Sao Feng's men without resistance, suggesting a possible lack of control in the situation.
Searches the room surreptitiously upon being escorted, showing caution and strategic thinking.
Refuses to treat people as cargo, valuing their humanity over profit.
Shows gratitude to Beckett for sparing him a worse fate, acknowledging kindness.
Assumes an air of questioning innocence when confronted about the missing item.
Uses sarcasm and playful behavior (pretending to sail model ships) during a tense conversation.
Assumes an air of questioning innocence to deflect Beckett's accusation, indicating cleverness and composure under pressure.
Counters Beckett’s claim about the heart of Davy Jones by asserting the matter settled, showing confidence and quick thinking.
Uses humor and distraction (pretending to sail model ships) to lighten the tension, demonstrating social skill but not necessarily competence in the serious matter.
Responds to Beckett’s emotional accusations calmly and with ironic gratitude, indicating emotional intelligence and confidence.
Refuses a seat on the board to Beckett citing lack of depravity or drunkenness; negotiates terms cautiously without immediate betrayal.
Engages Beckett in witty, playful negotiation, maintaining a personal monopoly on sensitive information.
Offers humorous advice and banter to Beckett despite mutual distrust.
Refuses an offer out of principle, showing awareness of his own limits.
Identifies Beckett's interest and negotiates for information in exchange for compensation and freedom.
Declines to divulge information, maintaining strategic control over valuable secrets.
Uses clever reasoning and role reversal to suggest a plan, showing strategic thinking and manipulation.
Dismisses Barbossa and Will Turner harshly, showing impatience and disdain.
Dismisses Barbossa and associates quickly, showing confident control over alliance choices.
Does not participate in the negotiation but asserts his own stance in a dismissive manner.
Extends his hand to Beckett to seal an accord despite mutual suspicion.
Responds evasively and sarcastically about Miss Swann when asked by Beckett.
Acknowledges Beckett's desire for the compass but warns of the consequences, showing strategic respect.
Negotiates a deal with Beckett to lead him to Shipwreck Cove, leveraging his unique knowledge and position.
Demonstrates cleverness by manipulating Beckett’s compass and reasoning about its implications, revealing a deep understanding of the situation.
Uses confident self-identification as 'Captain Jack Sparrow' to assert authority and maintain control in negotiation.
Shakes Beckett's extended hand to finalize a deal.
Lights a cannon to attempt a daring escape, showing boldness and inventiveness.
Greets Barbossa and Will with a smile and a light-hearted remark after crash landing.
Commands to send a traitor to the brig decisively, showing control over the situation.
No direct action or involvement shown in the excerpt; absence from leadership or decision-making moments.
Eavesdrops on Will's work and engages in teasing dialogue showing familiarity and subtle encouragement.
Mocks Will's plan but ultimately acknowledges his good intentions.
Does not raise an alarm despite an opportunity, showing trust or tolerance toward Will.
Escapes the brig quicker than expected, displaying cleverness and agility.
Detects the absence of an alarm and questions Will's actions, showing awareness and insight.
Lounge on the rail above forecastle, undetected for an unspecified long time.
Uses indirect verbal probing to test Will's intentions and plans.
Hands Will his compass, implying trust, then shoves him overboard playfully and smiles broadly.
Hands Will his compass with a cryptic hint, then shoves him overboard to force him into action, showing confidence and clever manipulation.
Smiles broadly and waves as he disappears, showing composure and control in a tense situation.
Makes a witty and insightful comment about pirates’ unimaginative naming convention, showing awareness and intelligence.
Does not give orders or take charge actively in the scene, remaining mostly observational.
Takes the wheel and warns about dangerous cross tides ahead, showing concern for the safety of others.
Comments humorously and self-deprecatingly that he owes all the gathered pirates money.
Takes the wheel and navigates dangerous cross tides skillfully.
Comments on the difficulty of the route and gives a knowing warning.
Acknowledges owing money to many pirates, implying risky or careless dealings.
Sails the Black Pearl to Shipwreck Cove, a strategic and dangerous location, indicating navigational and leadership skill.
Stabs his sword into the globe to join the Brethren Court meeting, showing assertiveness and symbolic leadership.
Flinches at the boom during the court meeting, showing a momentary lapse in confidence or composure.
Considers taking his piece of eight but ultimately does not, showing respect for the group agreement and patience to wait for Sao Feng
Considers taking action (reaching for the coin circlet) but then wisely refrains when observed by Barbossa, showing awareness and restraint.
States willingness to wait for Sao Feng to join despite the uncertainty about his status, showing patience and strategic timing.
Is called out by Villanueva, suggesting others see him as responsible or key, implying some level of competence attributed by peers.
Responds to Elizabeth's new captainship title with sarcastic dismissal ('Captain? Captain? They're just giving the title away now.')
Shrugs and admits Will is not among them when asked, showing detachment or limited openness.
Listens quietly and regards Elizabeth, calculating her words before responding or acting.
Dismisses the importance of the title 'Captain' by sarcastically saying 'They're just giving the title away now.'
Answers the question about Sao Feng's death confidently with 'Hers, I'll wager.'
Shrugs when asked about Will's whereabouts, indicating either lack of knowledge or unwillingness to engage.
Mocks the proposal to silence Barbossa by exaggerating the threat against him, showing quick wit and control of the situation.
Proposes realistic outcomes and acknowledges harsh truths about survival.
Encourages fighting together despite personal risk.
Defends himself against accusations by referring to pirate tradition humorously.
Analyzes the situation realistically, pointing out that staying holed up will result in inevitable deaths due to internal conflict.
Proposes releasing Calypso as a dangerous but possibly necessary option, showing strategic thinking and awareness of risks.
Quotes a Latin phrase to emphasize the inevitability of their situation, indicating intelligence and rhetorical skill.
Asserts that pirates must fight to run away, cleverly reframing a reputation of cowardice into a sound strategy.
Responds to Barbossa's accusation of running from fights with humor and deflection instead of direct confrontation.
Bangs cannon ball to gain attention and challenges Barbossa's claim about the Pirate King's authority by bluntly saying 'You made that up.'
Does not react to Akshay being shot and falling over, instead turns away and avoids acknowledging the shooting.
Steps aside respectfully when Captain Teague demands passage, showing deference despite personal feelings.
Questions Barbossa's statement about the Pirate King declaring an act of war by calling it made up, demonstrating skepticism and quick wit.
Does not react or look over when a pistol shot rings out and a pirate falls, seemingly calm or indifferent in a tense moment.
Steps aside for Captain Teague after being told 'You're in my way, boy,' showing deference to authority yet maintaining composure.
Insists on reading the passage himself despite Teague considering shooting him.
Calls for a vote including everyone present, showing inclusiveness.
Votes for Elizabeth Swann, showing trust and respect for her.
Smiles victoriously back at Barbossa after the pirate lords vow war, showing a confident and somewhat mocking demeanor.
Closes his eyes, aware and resigned to the betrayal happening behind him, indicating a sense of guardedness and mistrust.
Responds to Gibbs's remark about honesty with a cynical statement about survival, indicating defensiveness and emotional distance.
Directs Gibbs to ready the ship for battle, staying focused on practical matters despite personal tensions.
Smiles victoriously at Barbossa despite tense situation, showing calm confidence and control.
Closes eyes, knowingly aware of the betrayal unfolding behind him, demonstrating situational awareness and strategic insight.
Responds to Gibbs with a sharp reminder about readiness for battle, maintaining focus on priorities under pressure.
Feigns innocence when confronted by Gibbs, using deception skillfully to mask true intentions.
Accepts the shrunken head offered by Teague, nodding to an unspoken understanding.
Responds calmly to the sudden appearance of an overwhelming enemy fleet with the suggestion 'Parlay?'
Takes the shrunken head from Teague despite its oddness, showing willingness to engage with the situation thoughtfully.
Responds to a massive enemy fleet appearing with a calm suggestion of 'Parlay?'
Deflects blame for betrayal, maintains innocence ambiguously.
Catches the Compass tossed by Beckett, a symbol of his deal and possible betrayal.
Refuses to openly claim reward or acknowledge plans, exhibiting evasiveness.
Catches Beckett's tossed compass quickly, showing alertness and physical skill.
Denies involvement in Will's betrayal with a confident, sarcastic remark ('My hands are clean in this. Figuratively.'), managing to deflect direct blame.
Does not immediately assert control or reveal his full plan; admits the plan has no chance of success, showing awareness of the situation's reality.
Allows others (Beckett, Barbossa) to accuse him and put him on the spot without revealing much, maintaining an air of ambiguity and control.
Uses taunts and sarcasm ('There! Listen to the tool.') to undermine Will's credibility and keep others unsure of his true position.
Claims debt was paid 'with some help', implying cleverness and negotiation skills.
Doffs his hat and plays along with authority figures to conceal his true intentions.
Evades Barbossa’s attack but drops his circlet coin, a sign of momentary carelessness.
Engages in verbal sparring and physical maneuvering under pressure, showing confident behavior.
Jones shoves Jack down, indicating Jack was physically overpowered in that moment.
Drops the coin into Barbossa's hand as a courteous gesture to secure Elizabeth's position as King of the Brethren Court.
Engages in a sarcastic, somewhat playful dialogue with his other selves, showing wit but little sincere or friendly interaction with others.
Provides a coin to Barbossa, which leads to Barbossa's selection as King of the Brethren Court, demonstrating influence and strategic planning.
Appears calm and witty while imprisoned in the brig, engages in a clever internal dialogue represented by multiple versions of himself, showing self-awareness and mental agility.
Engages in humorous denial about saying 'poppycock' and gets mentally attacked by a version of himself, indicating moments of self-conflict or confusion.
Expresses pain and asks Wyvern Jack to stop squeezing his brain, indicating vulnerability and indirect communication.
No direct interaction with others in this excerpt; others discuss Jack but he remains passive or absent.
Momentarily confused by Wyvern Jack squeezing his brain; expresses pain and distraction.
Remembering something important after interruption, indicating sharp recall under pressure.
Tears out a bench and leverages it to break open the brig door to attempt escape with the other Jacks, encouraging them with 'Wish us luck, boys.'
Uses quick thinking and physical ingenuity to pry open the brig door by levering a bench, escaping captivity under cannon fire.
Murmurs 'Think like the whelp' repeatedly as a form of self-motivation and tactical focus.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Murtogg and Mullroy instead of confrontation.
Sneaks off with the chest while others are distracted arguing, showing cunning but also selfishness.
Calmly approaches the chest while the guards argue, picks it up, and sneaks off unnoticed.
Engages guards with witty banter to distract them.
Sheathes his sword and tips his hat before escaping on the sail, signaling politeness and flair despite conflict.
Offers to set Jones free during sword fight, showing willingness to help even an enemy.
Seeks escape rather than prolonged fight, indicating self-preservation over confrontation.
Identifies an escape route under pressure and executes a quick, improvised escape using a sail.
Successfully disarms the immediate situation by sheathing his sword and using the environment to his advantage.
Faces Jones and draws his sword confidently, engaging in a duel without hesitation.
Spars with Jones and claims to have the key, demonstrating confidence and cunning.
Fights aggressively against Davy Jones despite dangerous situation, prioritizing reclaiming the key.
Snaps sword in half during struggle, showing relentless determination rather than concern for cooperation or friendliness.
Heads toward retrieving his own pistol from an enemy, uses it immediately in combat.
Uses a bayline pin to block Jones' attack and skillfully maneuvers the capstan to defend himself.
Uses a bayline pin pulled from the capstan to block Jones' attack and spins the capstan to confuse Jones, showing quick thinking and improvisation in combat.
Draws a sword that is too small and cut in half, suggesting limited resources but adapts by using other items for defense.
Blocks Jones' attack despite having a broken sword, uses environment creatively to defend himself.
Grabs the key from the tentacle calmly under pressure and smiles, indicating composure and confidence.
Stands calmly holding Davy Jones' still-beating heart, squeezes it confidently to stagger Jones, showing control over a dire situation.
Hesitates after his sword is cut off, showing momentary uncertainty or lack of immediate reaction.
Grabs Elizabeth and gently pulls her away from the dying Will Turner, shielding her from the crowd despite her struggle and grief.
Stares across the abyss, contemplates the situation quietly instead of acting impulsively or harshly.
Stabs the heart of Davy Jones with a shortened sword, contributing critically to the defeat of Jones.
Looks at Will and Elizabeth, shows awareness of the gravity of the moment and acts to protect Elizabeth from approaching crewmen.
Pulls Elizabeth away from Will to protect her from grief and danger.
Fires pistol to cut sail ropes and escape imminent threat while ensuring Elizabeth’s safety.
Manages to comfort Elizabeth as they are lifted away, showing sensitivity to her mourning.
Dismisses pirate tradition when suggested by Gibbs, indicating independent or possibly dismissive attitude.
Cuts off his crew's protests decisively, commands them firmly with repeated orders to "Belay it! Stow it!"
Grins confidently as the Flying Dutchman appears and traps the Endeavour alongside the Black Pearl, demonstrating awareness and composure in a critical situation
Observes and reacts calmly during battle, commands firing on enemy ship with composure.
Notes the enemy retreat with some surprise, displays no malice or gloating, allows Gibbs to 'fling my hat' showing lightheartedness.
Commands the Black Pearl to fire on the enemy ship, actively engaging in battle with skill and decisiveness.
Observes the retreat of enemy ships calmly, commenting on the unusual sight with a mix of confidence and wit.
Waits next to the longboat to see Elizabeth off, shares a brief playful exchange with her.
Engages in a light-hearted, teasing conversation with Elizabeth about their relationship.
Does not attempt to stop Elizabeth as she turns away from a kiss, respecting her choice.
Brings Scarlett and Gisele to the docks and tries to impress them with his ship, using humorous exaggeration.
Allows Scarlett and Gisele to argue and bicker over who gets to ride on the Black Pearl first without intervening.
Describes the Black Pearl in an exaggerated, confusing way and fails to present his ship accurately (calling the small boat a dingy and claiming his vessel is ‘gone’).
Knows that the Black Pearl is out to sea but is unsure why it is gone and appears confused by the situation.
Admits to lying to the ladies and bluntly criticizes them ('no, I don't love you, of course it makes you look fat') to get their attention.
Expresses frustration about the loss of his ship and attempts to assert control in a chaotic moment.
Engages in banter with Gibbs, showing a familiar and somewhat affectionate relationship.
Realizes his ship is gone and immediately alerts others, trying to gain control of the situation despite distractions from the girls.
Attempts to command attention and prioritize the issue at hand, showing some leadership under pressure.
Fails to prevent the girls from disrupting the conversation and physically assaults himself to stop the fight, indicating somewhat chaotic conflict management.
Turns to gaze out at the horizon after receiving vague advice about sea turtles, showing contemplation and perhaps strategizing.
Relies on cryptic or unclear information from others (Gibbs) without evident immediate plan, possibly indicating uncertainty or strategic patience.
Smiles upon discovering the compass behavior, enjoys a quiet moment with rum, hums a pirate tune to himself as he sails alone into the sunset.
